title: Add pre-commit hooks for code quality enforcement
description:
Implement pre-commit hooks that enforce code quality standards without bypass options:

REQUIRED VALIDATIONS (must all pass):
- Minimum 80% test coverage across the codebase
- Maximum file length of 500 lines (enforce modular code)
- Type annotations required for all functions/methods
- No skipped tests allowed (no .skip() or similar)
- Zero warnings or linting errors

REQUIREMENTS:
- Use husky or similar for git hooks
- Hooks must run on pre-commit (blocking)
- NO bypass mechanisms (no --no-verify escape hatch)
- Clear error messages indicating which validation failed
- Reasonable execution time for commits (optimize for performance)

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
- All validations implemented and blocking commits
- Tests for hook functionality
- Documentation in README for developers
- Hooks installed automatically on npm install
- Performance optimized (consider lint-staged, parallel execution, caching)

comments.author: Amelia Payne
comments.text:
Gate Agent Rejection:
Pre-commit hook exceeds the 5-second execution time requirement
Details: The pre-commit check script takes ~10 seconds to complete, double the required <5 second threshold. The root cause is ESLint running redundantly: (1) explicitly in checkLint() and (2) again inside the pre-commit.test.js test which invokes 'npx eslint . --max-warnings 0' as a test assertion (line 98). Since the coverage check runs the full test:unit suite (which includes pre-commit.test.js), ESLint executes twice per pre-commit run. To fix: either exclude the ESLint test from the coverage/pre-commit test run, or restructure so linting isn't duplicated. All other requirements (husky setup, blocking hooks, 5 validations, tests, README docs, auto-install) are properly implemented.

comments.author: Amelia Payne
comments.text:
Gate Agent Rejection:
Pre-commit hook still exceeds 5-second execution time requirement
Details: The previous gate feedback identified that the pre-commit check exceeds the <5 second performance requirement. The fix attempt (commit d4f1d3f) changed execSync to exec with Promise.all to run lint and coverage in parallel, but this does NOT reduce wall-clock time because both ESLint (~3s) and c8+mocha (~3.8s) are CPU-bound Node.js processes that contend for the same CPU cores when run concurrently. Measured results: 3 runs averaged 10.8 seconds (range 6.4s–15.2s), well above the 5-second requirement. The parallelization approach is fundamentally flawed for CPU-bound tasks on a single machine. To actually meet the <5s target, the intern needs to either: (1) remove one of the expensive checks from the pre-commit hook (e.g., move coverage to CI), (2) use a faster linting approach (e.g., lint-staged to only lint changed files instead of the entire project), (3) cache ESLint results, or (4) restructure checks so coverage uses mocha directly instead of via npm (avoiding npm process spawn overhead). All other requirements (5 validations, husky, blocking hooks, no bypass, tests, README docs, auto-install) are correctly implemented.
